Chris Morris Christopher J Morris {{birth date and age|df[[Colchester]], [[Essex]], [[England]] Radio, television, print 1986–present [[Black humour]], [[satire]] [[Current events]] Christopher J"Chris"Morris(born 15 June 1962) is an English comedian, writer, director, actor, voice actor, and producer. He is known for hisblack humour,surrealism, and controversial subject matter, and has been hailed for his "uncompromising, moralistic drive" by theBritish Film Institute.cite webMorris, Christopher (1963– )http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/1392135/index.htmlBritish Film Institute29 December 2012His tendency to avoid the media spotlight has seen him become one of the more enigmatic figures in British comedy.

In the early 1990s, Morris teamed up with his radio producer,Armando Iannucci, to createOn The Hour, a satire of news programmes. This was expanded into a television spin off,The Day Today, which launched the career ofSteve Coogan, and has since been hailed as one of the most important satirical shows of the 1990s.cite newsElizabeth Dayhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/2010/apr/04/disgusting-bliss-chris-morris-biographyDisgusting Bliss by Lucian Randall | Book reviewThe ObserverGuardian4 April 201018 September 2013LondonMorris further developed the satirical news format withBrass Eye, which lampooned celebrities whilst focusing on themes such as crime and drugs. For many, the apotheosis of Morris's career was aBrass Eyespecial, which dealt with themoral panicsurroundingpaedophilia. It quickly became one of the most complained about programmes in British television history, leading theDaily Mailto describe him as "the most loathed man on TV".The Guardian (London) 21 February 2003 Review: CHRIS MORRIS: THE MOVIE: The last time he was in the news, it was for the 'paedophile special' of his TV series Brass Eye. Now he's made a film just 15 minutes long which is tipped to win a Bafta on Sunday. In a rare interview, Britain's greatest contemporary satirist talks to Xan Brooks about making the film, celebrities and why he won't be tackling the war on terror BYLINE: Xan Brooks

Meanwhile, Morris'spostmodernsketch andambient musicradio showBlue Jamhelped him to gain acult following. He went on to win aBAFTAfor Best Short Film after expanding aBlue Jamsketch intoMy Wrongs 82458249 & 117, which starredPaddy Considine. This was followed byNathan Barley, a sitcom written in collaboration with a then little-knownCharlie Brookerthat satirisedhipster (contemporary subculture)hipsters, which had low ratings but found success upon its DVD release. Morris followed this by joining the cast of theGraham LinehansitcomThe IT Crowd, his first project in which he did not have writing or producing input.

In 2010, Morris directed his first feature-length film,Four Lions, which satirisedIslamic terrorismthrough a group of ineptBritish Pakistanis. Reception of the film was largely positive, earning Morris his second BAFTA, for "Outstanding Debut". Since 2012, he has directed four episodes of Iannucci's political comedyVeep (TV series)Veepand appeared onscreen inThe Double (2013 film)The DoubleandStewart Lee's Comedy Vehicle.
article.heading: Biography
Early life
article.paragraph: Morris was born inColchester,Essex,cite webhttp://search.findmypast.co.uk/results/world-records/england-and-wales-births-1837-2006?firstnamefindmypast.co.uksearch.findmypast.co.uk5 October 2014to father Paul Michael Morris, ageneral practitionerGP,cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/7594826/Disgusting-Bliss-the-Brass-Eye-of-ChrisMorris-by-Lucian-Randall-review.htmlDisgusting Bliss: the Brass Eye of Chris Morris by Lucian Randall: reviewTelegraph15 April 201018 September 2013LondonSameerRahimand mother Rosemary Parringtoncite bookDisgusting Bliss: The Brass Eye of Chris MorrisRandall, L.2010Simon & Schuster UK9780857200907http://books.google.co.uk/books?id5 October 2014and grew up in aVictorian eraVictorianfarmhouse in the villageBuckden, CambridgeshireBuckden,Huntingdonshire, which he describes as "very dull".If It Bleeds It Leads 6 June 1994 By Simon Price From The Melody Maker

He has two younger brothers, including theatre directorTom Morris (director)Tom Morris.Profile: Chris Morris, BBC Radio 4From an early age he was a prankster, and also had a passion for radio. From the age of 10 he was educated atStonyhurst College, an independentSociety of JesusJesuitboarding school inLancashire.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1460463.stmChris Morris: Brass Neck23 June 200827 July 2001BBC NewsThe son of two Cambridgeshire GPs, Chris Morris was educated at Stonyhurst CollegeHe went to studyzoologyat theUniversity of Bristol, where he gained a 2:1.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2001/jul/22/comment.euanfergusonThe Observer Profile: Chris Morris23 June 2008FergusonEuan22 July 2001[[The Observer]]London
article.heading: Radio career
article.paragraph: On graduating, Morris pursued a career as a musician in various bands, for which he played the bass guitar. He then went to work for Radio West, a local radio station in Bristol. He then took up a news traineeship withBBC Radio Cambridgeshire, where he took advantage of access to editing and recording equipment to create elaborateParodyspoofsandparodyparodies.cite newsAndy Becketthttp://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/prank-master-chris-morriss-announcement-of-the-death-of-michael-heseltine-on-radio-1-was-just-one-among-many-notorious-japes-his-satire-is-big-with-the-media-but-how-popular-is-it-with-listeners-1377835.htmlPrank master: Chris Morris's announcement of the death of Michael Heseltine on Radio 1 was just one among many notorious japes. His satire is big with the media, but how populIndependent.co.uk21 August 199418 September 2013LondonHe also spent time in early 1987 hosting a 24pm afternoon show and finally ended up presenting Saturday morning showI.T.

In July 1987, he moved on toBBC Radio Bristolto present his own show "No Known Cure", broadcast on Saturday and Sunday mornings. The show was surreal and satirical, with odd interviews conducted with unsuspecting members of the public. He was fired from Bristol in 1990 after "talking over the news bulletins and making silly noises".Morris, the man with a mission to cause offence. Daily Mail (London)In 1988 he also joined, from its launch,BBC London 94.9Greater London Radio(GLR). He presentedThe Chris Morris Showon GLR until 1993, when one show got suspended after a sketch was broadcast involving a child "outing" celebrities.cite webhttp://www.pbjmgt.co.uk/artist/chris-morrisChris Morris / Artists / PBJ – THE exclusive UK-based talent agency. Clients include the best performers, presenters, writers, composers, directors and producersPbjmgt.co.uk18 September 2013

In 1991, Morris joinedArmando Iannucci's spoof news projectOn the Hour. Broadcast onBBC Radio 4, it saw him work alongside Iannucci,Steve Coogan,Stewart Lee,Richard HerringandRebecca Front. In 1992, Morris hostedDanny Baker's Radio 5 Morning Edition show for a week whilst Baker was on holiday. In 1994, Morris began a weekly evening show, theChris Morris Music Show, onBBC Radio 1alongsidePeter Baynhamand 'man with a mobile phone'Paul Garner (comedian)Paul Garner. In the shows, Morris perfected the spoof interview style that would become a central component of hisBrass Eyeprogramme. In the same year, Morris teamed up withPeter Cook, asSir Arthur Streeb-Greebling, in a series of improvised conversations forBBC Radio 3, entitledWhy Bother? (radio show)Why Bother?.
article.heading: Move into television and film

template.arg: If you make a joke in an area which is for some reason, normally random, out of bounds, then you might find something out, you might put your finger on something.

article.paragraph: In 1994, aBBC TwoBBC 2television series based onOn the Hourwas broadcast under the nameThe Day Today.The Day Todaymade a star of Morris, and marked the television debut of Steve Coogan'sAlan Partridgecharacter. The programme ended on a high after just one series, with Morris winning the 1994British Comedy Awardfor Best Newcomer for his lead role as theJeremy PaxmanPaxmanesquenews anchor.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1460805.stmUK | Chris Morris: Brass NeckBBC News27 July 200118 September 2013

In 1997, theblack comedyblack humourwhich had featured inOn the HourandThe Day Todaybecame more prominent inBrass Eye, another spoof current affairs television documentary, shown onChannel 4.Brass Eyebecame known for tricking celebrities and politicians into throwing support behind public awareness campaigns for made-up issues that were often absurd or surreal (such as a drug calledcakeand an elephant with its trunk stuck up itsanus).

From 1997 to 1999 Morris createdBlue JamforBBC Radio 1, a surreal taboo-breaking radio show set to an ambient soundtrack.In 2000 this was followed byJam (TV series)Jam, a television reworking.Morris released a 'remix' version of this, entitledJaaaaam.

In 2001, a special episode ofBrass Eyeon themoral panicthat surroundspedophiliapaedophilialed to a record-breaking number of complaints it still remains the third highest on UK television afterCelebrity Big Brother 2007 (UK)Celebrity Big Brother 2007andJerry Springer: The Operaas well as heated discussion in the press. Many complainants, some of whom later admitted to not having seen the programme (notablyBeverley Hughes, a government minister),cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1335865/Minister-in-Brass-Eye-protest-has-not-even-seen-it.htmlMinister in Brass Eye protest has not even seen itAndyMcSmith[[The Daily Telegraph]]31 July 200120 May 2009Londonfelt the satire was directed at the victims of paedophilia, which Morris denies. Channel 4 defended the show, insisting the target was the media and its hysterical treatment of paedophilia, and not victims of crime.

In 2002, Morris ventured into film, directing theshort filmshortMy Wrongs 82458249 & 117My Wrongs#82458249 & 117, adapted from aBlue Jammonologue about a man led astray by a sinister talking dog. It was the first film project ofWarp Films, a branch ofWarp Records. In 2002 this won theBritish Academy of Film and Television ArtsBAFTAfor best short film.In 2005 Morris worked on a sitcom entitledNathan Barley, based on the character created byCharlie Brookerfor his websiteTVGoHome(Morris had contributed to TVGoHome on occasion, under the pseudonym 'Sid Peach'cite webBrookerCharlieFULL SESSION - The Alternative MacTaggart: Charlie Brookerhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?vYouTubeGuardian Edinburgh International Television Festival14 January 2015). Co-written by Brooker and Morris, the series was broadcast onChannel 4in early 2005.
article.heading: Post 2005
article.paragraph: Morris was a cast member inThe IT Crowd, aChannel 4sitcom which focused on the information technology department of the fictional company Reynholm Industries. The series was written and directed byGraham Linehan(writer ofFather TedandBlack Books, with whom Morris collaborated onThe Day Today,Brass EyeandJam) and produced byAsh Atalla(The Office (UK TV series)The Office). Morris played Denholm Reynholm, the eccentric managing director of the company. This marked the first time Morris has acted in a substantial role in a project which he has not developed himself. Morris's character appeared to leave the series during episode two of the second series. His character made a brief return in the first episode of the third series.

In November 2007, Morris wrote an article forThe Observerin response toRonan Bennett's article published six days earlier inThe Guardian. Bennett's article, "Shame on us", accused the novelistMartin Amisof racism. Morris's response, "The absurd world of Martin Amis", was also highly critical of Amis; although he did not accede to Bennett's accusation of racism, Morris likened Amis to the Muslim clericAbu Hamza al-MasriAbu Hamza(who was jailed forinciting racial hatredin 2006), suggesting that both men employ "mock erudition, vitriol and decontextualised quotes from the Qu'ran" to incite hatred.cite newsMorrisChrishttp://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2007/nov/25/bookscomment.religionThe absurd world of Martin AmisThe Observer25 November 200722 June 2008Last week Amis was called a racist. I saw him speak at the ICA last month. Was his negativity about Islam technically racist? I don't know. What I can tell you is that Martin Amis is the new Abu Hamza. [...] Like Hamza, Amis could only make his nonsense stand up with mock erudition, vitriol and decontextualised quotes from the Koran.London

Morris served as script editor for the 2009 seriesStewart Lee's Comedy Vehicle, working with former colleaguesStewart Lee,Kevin EldonandArmando Iannucci. He maintained this role for the second (2011) and third series (2014).

Morris completed his debut feature filmFour Lionsin late 2009, a satire based on a group of Islamist terrorists in Sheffield.cite webhttp://www.bleedingcool.com/2009/07/17/set-shot-from-chris-morris-four-lions/Set shot from Chris Morris' Four LionsBleeding Cool.com26 July 2009It premiered at theSundance Film Festivalin January 2010 and was short-listed for the festival's World Cinema Narrative prize.cite webhttp://festival.sundance.org/2010/press_industry/releases/2010_sundance_film_festival_announces_films_in_competition/2010 SUNDANCE FILM FESTIVAL ANNOUNCES FILMS IN COMPETITION | Sundance Festival 2010Festival.sundance.org20 August 2010The film (working titleBoilerhouse) was picked up byFilm Four.cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/wannabe-suicide-bombers-beware-chris-morris-movie-gets-goahead-1228152.htmlWannabe suicide bombers beware: Chris Morris movie gets go-aheadGenevièveRoberts6 January 200920 May 2009The IndependentLondonMorris toldThe Sunday Timesthat the film sought to do for Islamic terrorism whatDad's Army, the classic BBC comedy, did for the Nazis by showing them as "scary but also ridiculous".cite newsBrooksRichardhttp://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article3177654.eceSatirist turns terrorists into Dad's Army[[The Sunday Times]]13 January 200813 January 2008London

In 2012, Morris directed the seventh and penultimate episode of the first season ofVeep (TV series)Veep, an Armando Iannucci-devised American version ofThe Thick of It.Citationhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt2161219/Veep: Season 1, Episode 7 Full Disclosure (3 Jun. 2012)[[Internet Movie Database]]23 May 2012In 2013, he returned to direct two episodes for the second season ofVeep, and a further episode for season three in 2014.

In 2013, Morris appeared briefly in Richard Ayoade'sThe Double (2013 film)''The Double'', a black comedy film based on theFyodor DostoyevskyThe Double (Fyodor Dostoyevsky novel)novella of the same name. Morris had previously worked with Ayoade onNathan BarleyandThe IT Crowd.

In February 2014, Morris made a surprise appearance at the beginning of aStewart Leelive show, introducing the comedian with fictional anecdotes about their work together.cite webChortleChris Morris, live on stagehttp://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2014/02/16/19608/chris_morris,_live_on_stage?rss&utm_sourceChortle17 February 2014The following month, Morris appeared in the third series ofStewart Lee's Comedy Vehicleas a "hostile interrogator",cite webLeeStewartThe material is cooking with gashttp://www.chortle.co.uk/features/2014/02/19/19633/the_material_is_cooking_with_gasChortle19 February 2014a role previously occupied by Armando Iannucci.

In December 2014, it was announced that a short radio collaboration withNoel Fieldingand Richard Ayoade would be broadcast on BBC Radio 6.cite webBBCChris Morris Exclusivehttp://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04tm3qbhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/programmesBBC1 December 2014According to an interview with Fielding in 2011, the work had already been in progress for five years by that point.cite webNoel Fielding: Radio Past and Futurehttp://thevelvetonion.com/2011/11/03/radio-past-and-future/http://thevelvetonion.com/The Velvet Onion1 December 2014However, it was decided, 'in consultation with [Morris]', that the project was not yet complete enough, and so the intended broadcast did not go ahead.cite webNew Chris Morris sketch 'not ready yet'http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2014/12/08/21449/new_chris_morris_sketch_not_ready_yetwww.chortle.co.ukChortle14 January 2015
article.heading: Music
article.paragraph: Morris often co-writes and performs incidental music for his television shows, notably withJamand the 'extended remix' version,Jaaaaam. In the early 1990s Morris contributed aPixiesparody track entitled "Motherbanger" to aFlexi discflexi-discgiven away with an edition ofselect magazineSelectmusic magazine.cite webhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vChris Morris – Mother Banger (Pixies Parody)Morris supplied sketches for British bandSaint Etienne (band)Saint Etienne's 1993 single "You're in a Bad Way" (the sketch 'Spongbake' appears at the end of the 4th track on the CD single).In 2000, he collaborated by mail withAmon Tobinto create the track "Bad Sex", which was released as a B-side on the Tobin single "Slowly".cite webhttp://www.discogs.com/Amon-Tobin-Slowly/release/29172Amon Tobin (feat Chris Morris at DiscogsDiscogs.com21 May 200220 August 2010British bandStereolab's song "Nothing to Do with Me" from their 2001 albumSound-Dustfeatured various lines from Chris Morris sketches as lyrics.cite webhttp://www.nme.com/news/stereolab/8265Stereolab's 'Jam' Session[[NME]]21 June 200120 May 2009
article.heading: Recognition
article.paragraph: In 2003, Morris was listed inThe Observeras one of the 50 funniest acts in British comedy.cite newshttp://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,11710,1101525,00.htmlThe A-Z of laughter (part two)The Observer7 December 200313 January 2008LondonIn 2005,Channel 4aired a show calledThe Comedian's Comedianin which foremost writers and performers of comedy ranked their 50 favourite acts. Morris was at number eleven.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4141019.stmCook voted 'comedians' comedian'23 June 20082 January 2005BBC NewsModern TV satirist Chris Morris was in 11th, followed by Tony Hancock, Bill Hicks, Peter Sellers and Steve Martin.Morris won the BAFTA for outstanding debut with his filmFour Lions. Adeel Akhtar and Nigel Lindsay collected the award in his absence.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12432378BBC NewsKing's Speech reigns over Bafta awards14 February 2011Lindsay stated that Morris had sent him a text message before they collected the award reading, 'Doused in petrol,Zippoat the ready'.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2011/feb/13/baftas-2011-the-kings-speechThe GuardianBaftas 2011: The King's Speech sweeps the board14 February 2011LondonMarkBrownIn June 2012 Morris was placed at number 16 in the Top 100 People in UK Comedy.cite newshttp://www.suchsmallportions.com/feature/top-100-most-influential-people-comedy-20-1The Top 100 most influential people in comedy: 20 – 1ClarkTim22 June 2012Such Small Portions23 August 2012

In 2010, a biography,Disgusting Bliss: The Brass Eye of Chris Morris, was published. Written by Lucian Randall, the book depicted Morris as "brilliant but uncompromising", and a "frantic-minded perfectionist".cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/culture/2010/apr/04/disgusting-bliss-chris-morris-biographyDisgusting Bliss by Lucian RandallDayElizabeth4 June 2010The Guardian7 April 2014

In November 2014, a three-hour retrospective of Morris' radio career was broadcast onBBC Radio 4 Extraunder the title 'Raw Meat Radio', presented byMary Anne Hobbsand featuring interviews withArmando Iannucci,Peter Baynham,Paul Garner (comedian)Paul Garner, and others.cite webBlackSophieBBC - Raw Meat Radiohttp://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/proginfo/2014/48/raw-meat-radiohttp://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre29 November 2014
article.heading: Awards
article.paragraph: Morris won theBritish Comedy Awards winnersBest TV Comedy Newcomeraward from the British Comedy Awards in 1998 for his performance inThe Day Today.cite webhttp://www.britishcomedyawards.com/past-winners/1994.aspxBritish Comedy Awards: 1994 winners23 June 2008He has won twoBAFTAawards: theBAFTA Award for Best Short Filmin 2002 forMy Wrongs 82458249 & 117My Wrongs#82458249 & 117,cite webhttp://www.bafta.org/awards/film/nominations/?yearBAFTA: Film Nominations 200223 June 2008and the BAFTA Award for Outstanding Debut by a British director, writer or producer in 2011 forFour Lions.cite webhttp://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?yearAwards database8 March 2011
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: Morris lives inBrixton, with his wife, actress turned literary agent Jo Unwin.cite newsMaherKevinThe return of the most hated man in BritainThe Times3 April 2012The pair met in 1984 at theEdinburgh Festival, when he was playing bass guitar for theCambridge FootlightsRevue and she was in a comedy troupe called the Millies.They have two sons, Charles and Frederick, both of whom were born inLondon Borough of LambethLambeth.Until the release ofFour Lionshe gave very few interviews and little had been published about Morris's personal life. Since 2009 he has made numerous media appearances to promote and support the film, both in the UK and USA, at one point appearing as a guest onLate Night with Jimmy Fallon.

Morris can be heard as himself in a 2008 podcast forCERN.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/science/audio/2008/jun/30/cern.chris.morris.podcastCern podcast: Chris Morris visits the Large Hadron ColliderThe Guardian30 June 200820 May 2009London
